item.title: Undergraduate Researcher Kristian Gubsch Receives Distinguished Scholarship to Fund Graduate Education
item.dc:creator: daniel.rieck
item.content:encoded:
PULLMAN, Wash.—Washington State University chemical engineering senior Kristian Gubsch is headed in the fall to the United Kingdom’s University of Sheffield as WSU’s first recipient of a Marshall Scholarship for graduate study.

Gubsch has participated in undergraduate research since his freshman year on topics related to his career goals, and, in addition to numerous scholarships, has received three prestigious, nationally competitive awards to support his education.

He is one of 46 American students to receive the award nationally for 2020, and is the only recipient from Washington and the Pacific Northwest.

“We are extremely proud to have Kristian as our first Marshall Scholar,” said WSU President Kirk Schulz, who submitted an institutional endorsement letter. “He is a remarkable student, scientist, entrepreneur, and leader whose impactful research, national awards, and international collaborations lead to an obvious conclusion: He will play a significant role in developing clean-energy technology and will impact critical climate-change conversations. We are excited for this Cougar’s future and the impact he will have on the future of the world.”

“I have had an amazing set of experiences as an undergraduate, in classes and otherwise, but I wasn’t sure if I’d next go to graduate school or get a job in the CO2-utilization industry,” said Gubsch, a member of the WSU Honors College. “Receiving the Marshall made up my mind and sets the path for my immediate future. I’m really excited to head to England to study with another set of world-class scientists like those at WSU.”

The Marshall is Gubsch’s third distinguished scholarship received while an undergraduate. Those awards encompass a small set of prestigious and nationally competitive scholarships available to U.S. students. He is WSU’s first student to receive an Ernest F. Hollings Undergraduate Scholarship from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) in 2018, and for 2019-20 he was awarded the Barry Goldwater Scholarship and Excellence in Education Program award. He has also received numerous campus leadership awards.

Importance of the Marshall

The Marshall award was founded in 1953 by the British Parliament and named to honor former U.S. Secretary of State George C. Marshall and commemorate “the humane ideals of the Marshall Plan” following World War II. Each year, there may be up to 50 students awarded a Marshall. Applicants from eight regions of America are evaluated on academic merit and leadership and ambassadorial potential to improve U.K.-U.S. understanding. Scholars must have earned baccalaureate degrees in STEM, humanities, social sciences, and creative arts fields, and are funded by the Marshall to do graduate study with research at any of more than 150 British universities. Notable Marshall alumni include Pulitzer Prize winners, Academy Award nominees, Supreme Court justices, a NASA astronaut, and a Nobel Laureate.

Why the University of Sheffield

Gubsch carefully selected the University Sheffield, in Yorkshire, as his university of choice for the Marshall. There he will seek a master’s degree in energy and environmental engineering working with faculty mentor Peter Styring. Styring is a world leader in techniques to utilize carbon dioxide and chair of the CO2 ChemNetwork, the largest global network of researchers, industry professionals, and policymakers involved in the utilization of carbon dioxide for the manufacture of chemicals, minerals, and fuels. The U.K. Centre for Carbon Dioxide Utilization is also located at Sheffield.

In his second year as a Marshall at Sheffield, Gubsch will pursue an international business degree focused on management. He believes it will further prepare him for his career by developing the skills necessary to begin global commercialization and implementation of technology to capture carbon dioxide from its sources. These gasses would otherwise be emitted into the atmosphere, contributing to climate change; Gubsch envisions ways and means to convert it into valuable chemicals.

It was through use of his strategic leadership and networking skills that Gubsch found his way to the University of Sheffield with further plans for a pdoctoral degree back in the U.S. He had visited California’s Silicon Valley as part of the Harold Frank Engineering Entrepreneurship Institute program in the Voiland College of Engineering and Architecture. He shared his interest in carbon capture technology and was advised to contact faculty at Stony Brook University in New York. Conversations there led him to the Global CO2 Initiative at the University of Michigan’s Energy Institute, which led him to scientist Styring in the U.K.

As the University of Sheffield is a research partner with the University of Michigan’s Global CO2 Initiative—the only research initiative in the U.S. with a focus on CO2 utilization—Gubsch intends that his Marshall experience will help him return to the U.S. for his Ph.D. studies there in 2023.

Why the University of Sheffield

Gubsch set his sights on an education and career focused in improving global climate issues while still at Fife High School; his family in Edgewood, Wash., includes Derek and Deborah Reece, and brother Evan. He plans to enter the carbon-dioxide utilization industry and become a leader in the field “by applying (his) several years of experience developing the technology to the practical integration of the technology into our industrial framework.”

At WSU, the Honors College senior is co-facilitating a first-year course for Honors students and has pursued since his freshman year several undergraduate research opportunities with mentoring faculty members. His work has involved investigations of air quality as well as carbon capture and conversions from carbon dioxide to calcium formate. As part of his NOAA award, he spent a summer in South Carolina at the National Institute of Standards and Technology examining ocean acidification and its impact on coral.

Gubsch applied for the Marshall at the encouragement of Honors Dean M. Grant Norton, Honors Associate Dean Robin Bond, and Distinguished Scholarships Program Director April Seehafer. He said he was reluctant at first, since the Marshall is open to a large, diverse set of students from all fields and would be very competitive.

“I thought, ‘What chance do I have to compete against students from Ivy League schools?’ But one thing I’ve learned from applying for other awards I’ve won and opportunities I’ve reached out for is that I have to be open to all kinds of opportunities because I can’t be sure of what I’ll get. I have learned to be open to being vulnerable.

“I went to the regional interview in San Francisco pretty composed, having done practice interviews at WSU. I reminded myself to be as articulate as possible. I thought I did pretty well, but when I got word that I’d actually won the Marshall I was excited, but for many reasons, it’s all still sinking in. Mostly now, I’m just concerned with this semester’s schoolwork, group projects, and final exams. As chair of the student group of the American Institute of Chemical Engineers, I’m also helping organize a regional spring conference here. I’ll think more about the Marshall and the many opportunities it opens up over winter break.”

A COP25 NGO Observer This Month

December is an especially busy month for Gubsch. He’s one of a handful of students selected nationally to travel to Madrid, Spain, as a “student-professional correspondent” representing the American Chemical Society at the United Nations Climate Action Summit as an “NGO observer.” The students are charged with helping promote climate science literacy among college and university students, will share information from the conference via blogs and social media, will write a chapter on a topic for an upcoming book, and will present at an ACS conference this spring.

The global climate-change summit Gubsch will attend, COP25 (Conference of Parties), is predicted to be the largest UN-sponsored gathering of climate change experts and policymakers held throughout the world in 2019. The COP is famous for negotiating the Paris Agreement in 2014, a plan to decrease global warming and deal with various impacts of greenhouse-gas emissions; the agreement is endorsed by nearly 200 nations worldwide.

Gubsch’s COP25-related blog entries are linked to from the homepage of the WSU’s Distinguished Scholarships website.

MEDIA: April Seehafer, WSU Distinguished Scholarships Program director, 509-335-8239, seehafer@wsu.edu

Kristian Gubsch, WSU’s first Marshall Scholar, kristian.gubsch@wsu.edu

item.title: Undergraduate Research Award Applications Open through Feb. 15, 2020
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded:
MEDIA: Shelley Pressley, director of the WSU Office of Undergraduate Research, 509-335-0014, UG.research@wsu.edu

PULLMAN, Wash.—Washington State University students can apply online now through Feb. 15 for awards to support their mentored research, scholarship, and creative activities in academic year 2020-21, announced Shelley Pressley, director of the Office of Undergraduate Research.

“Thanks to the vision of generous donors, recipients of these awards—students from all majors and campuses—can afford to spend more time concentrating on their research efforts rather than having to work at a job,” said Shelley Pressley, director of the Office of Undergraduate Research, part of the Division of Academic Engagement and Student Achievement (DAESA).

Four types of awards are offered. Two are presented by the Office of Undergraduate Research, one is from the Voiland College of Engineering and Architecture, and another is awarded by WSU LSAMP (Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation), an NSF-funded program for underrepresented minority students in STEM majors.

Applying is easy

Applicants must provide information on their research; a letter of reference from their research mentor is required.

“The process is very easy for students, and mentors are eager to explain how and why the applicant qualifies for an award. We encourage all students to consider this opportunity,” said Pressley.

Select from four awards

The application form asks applicants to select among the four awards, with the option to choose more than one.

The Auvil Scholars Fellowship is for undergraduates in all majors, campuses, and years in college. This fund was created in 2006 from an estate gift by Grady and Lillie Auvil, Wenatchee tree-fruit entrepreneurs. Hundreds of undergraduates across WSU have received funding from this award and become Auvil Fellows during their baccalaureate program.

The Scott and Linda Carson Undergraduate Research Excellence Award is the first university-wide undergraduate research award that gives preference to recipients who are upper-division students (juniors and seniors). The fund was created in 2013 by the Carson’s, WSU alumni who have long supported WSU with their service and financial gifts. 

The DeVlieg Foundation Award was established by a private tax-exempt charity to support sophomore and junior students in the WSU Voiland College of Engineering and Architecture who are pursuing research into renewable energy. Applicants must have a 3.0 GPA. Recipients of the award are known as DeVlieg Fellows.

WSL LSAMP Research Awards are for LSAMP program participants at Pullman who are pursuing a science, technology, engineering, or mathematics discipline. The program serves students who are Native-Alaskan/Native American, African American/Black, Pacific Islander, Hispanic/Latino, and/or two or more faces when mixed with any of these previously stated races. Applicants must have an overall 3.0 or higher GPA. Working with a faculty mentor, they commit to a full academic year of working on a research project. Awardees are known as WSU LSAMP Research Fellows.

More information

For more information and for the online application form, visit the awards page on the undergraduate research website at https://undergraduateresearch.wsu.edu/funding/undergraduate-research-awards/ .

item.title: NCUR abstract submissions open
item.dc:creator: daniel.rieck
item.content:encoded: From Oct. 3 - Dec. 5, 2017, abstracts may be submitted to present at the 32nd annual National Conference on Undergraduate Research in April 2018. NCUR, established in 1987, is dedicated to promoting undergraduate research, scholarship, and creative activity in all fields of study by sponsoring the annual conference for students. These conferences are designed to gather young scholars and welcome presenters from all institutions of higher learning and from all corners of the academic curriculum. The theme of this year's conference will be "Connection to Place."

item.title: SACNAS abstract submissions close
item.dc:creator: daniel.rieck
item.content:encoded: The Society for Advancement of Chicanos/Hispanics and Native Americans in Science (SACNAS) is an inclusive organization dedicated to fostering the success of Chicano/Hispanic and Native American scientists, from college students to professionals, in attaining advanced degrees, careers, and positions of leadership in STEM. Undergraduate researchers are invited to apply to present their research during a judged poster session at the October 2017 conference; abstracts must be submitted online by the deadline.

item.title: ABRCMS abstract submissions open
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded:
From April 5 through Sept. 8, 2017, students can submit abstracts to make a poster or oral presentation at the November 2017 Annual Biomedical Research Conference for Minority Students (ABRCMS). ABRCMS is one of the largest communities of underrepresented minorities in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics. Students attend this conference to present their research, explore graduate schools, and network. Research faculty and program directors play an essential role in mentoring students and strategies for facilitating student success.

During the four-day conference, more than 1,800 students from over 350 colleges and universities participate in poster and oral presentations in 12 STEM disciplines. All undergraduate student presentations are judged and those receiving the highest scores in each scientific discipline will be given an award during the closing banquet.

item.title: CUR Posters on the Hill abstract submissions open
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: From Sept. 6 – Nov. 1, 2017, abstracts may be submitted to present in spring 2018 at the 22nd annual Council on Undergraduate Research (CUR) poster session on Capitol Hill in Washington, D.C.  At an evening poster session and reception, student will have the opportunity to speak directly to members of Congress and demonstrate how they have been impacted by undergraduate research programs.  Undergraduate research must be among the programs that Congresspeople understand if it is to continue to be supported and grow, according to the CUE website.

item.title: CUR Biology travel grant app deadline
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: The Council for Undergraduate Research (CUR) Biology Division is offering a limited number of travel grants of up to $250 each for undergraduate students presenting original, biological research results at a regional or national, discipline-specific meeting during fiscal year 2017-2018. Award recipients are required to acknowledge CUR for support of their travel in their talk or poster, to complete an online survey about their meeting experience, and to submit a PDF file of their poster. Minority students are encouraged to apply. Submission deadlines are September 1, 2017 (for meetings held in mid-Sept 2017 to mid-Feb 2018) and January 12, 2018 (for meetings held in mid-Feb to late June 2018). For further details or to apply, visit the division's travel awards webpage.

item.title: CUR Physics & Astronomy travel grant deadline
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: The CUR Physics and Astronomy Division offers travel awards of up to $500 each to help support students who will present at CUR events or other professional meetings relevant to the division. Applications for travel awards must include a one-page letter outlining the nature of the meeting, a brief budget, and an abstract of the paper(s) or poster(s) to be presented. Applicants’ mentors must be CUR members. Submit all materials to division chair Terry Oswalt. Due dates for applications are September 15, 2017, at 5 pm EDT and March 16, 2018, at 5 pm.

Award recipients are required to acknowledge CUR for support of their travel in their talk or poster, to complete a short evaluation in either written or video form about their meeting experience, and to submit a PDF file of their poster. item.title: WSU Summer Undergraduate Research Symposium
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: WSU students involved in mentored research in summer 2017 may be eligible to present a poster on their work at this annual summer event. Many other student presenters are from other universities who have spent more than two months on the WSU campus in Pullman engaged in mentored research and sponsored by the National Science Foundation, the U.S.D.A., and faculty grants. Check with your mentor about presenting at the symposium.

item.title: Summer undergraduate research information session
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded:
Hear about summer undergraduate research opportunities, at WSU and beyond!  In fact, they are available around the globe.  They provide opportunities to travel, gain experience, and maybe even get paid.  Presented by Shelley Pressley, director of the WSU Office of Undergraduate Research, topics at the session will cover how to find a summer-research opportunity, an overview of the application process, and information about the kinds of programs available. 

All undergraduates interested in learning more about these experiences are encouraged to attend this session.

Wednesday, November 29, 2017 from 5:05pm-5:50pm in CUE 419

item.title: DOE Cleanup at Hanford: Lecture by alumnus Thomas W. Fletcher
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded:
Thomas W. Fletcher ('BS 2000 Civil Engineering; 'MS 2002 Civil Engineering) is the deputy manager of the Dept. of Energy's Richard Operations Office in Washington.  He will deliver this annual DOE Lecture Series presentation, "Richland Operations Office 101," in person at WSU Tri-Cities, with broadcasts to Pullman, Vancouver, Everett, and Spokane locations.  (Find those locations on the AMS calendar at ams.wsu.edu/RequestForm/EventsCalendar.aspx under Nov. 8, 3-4 p.m.)

Questions: Contact Tish Christman at 509-372-7683 (WSU Tri-Cities)

Fletcher’s lecture will focus on the Richland Operations Office’s priorities for continuing the cleanup of the Hanford Site, explaining how their office,
with an annual budget of approximately $1 billion and multiple contractors under his oversight, continues to progress in their mission at the 580-square-mile Hanford Site while adhering to safe, environmentally acceptable and responsible management.

He will also discuss the Richland Operations Office’s priorities for the next several years.

Fletcher became Deputy Manager of the Richland Operations Office in December 2016. He has oversight of daily operations, program planning, project execution, budgeting, and compliance with the Hanford Federal Facility Agreement and Consent Order (Tri-Party Agreement).

With more than 20 years of experience managing nuclear operations, construction, deactivation and demolition, and environmental remediation projects, Fletcher was previously Assistant Manager at the Office of River Protection for Waste Treatment and Immobilization Plant Start-Up, Commissioning, and Integration; responsible for engineering, procurement, construction, nuclear safety, hazardous waste management,
and operations of the Hanford tank farms.

Prior to coming to Hanford, he served at the U.S. Department of Army Corps of Engineers Walla Walla District as a co-lead for the Richland Operations Life Cycle Cost Baseline, the foundation for the $3 billion Mission Support Contract and $7 billion Plateau Remediation Contract.

Fletcher holds bachelors and masters degrees in civil engineering from Washington State University, and is a registered professional engineer in Washington and a certified project management professional through the Project Management Institute.

item.title: SURCA 2018 (Showcase for Undergraduate Research and Creative Activities)
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: The seventh annual Showcase for Undergraduate Research and Creative Activities (SURCA) will be the afternoon of Monday, April 2, 2018 in the CUB Ballrooms.  Up to 250 students from all majors, years in college, and campuses will present posters and describe their mentored research, scholarship, and creative activities in eight categories. Judges, using a rubric, will evaluate presentations and offer feedback to every student. Awards will be presented at the close of the event. For more information, to submit an abstract or sign up to judge (there are deadlines for both), to see results of prior SURCA events, and much more, visit https://surca.wsu.edu.

item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: FIND US AT CONNECT FEST:  The campus and community involvement jamboree.  Look for Undergraduate Research Club members and officers at this Registered Student Organization event. Ask about our club and upcoming events.  Open to all majors in all years of college.

item.title: Undergraduate Research Club (Go Where?)
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: WHAT WOULD YOU LIKE TO TOUR ON CAMPUS?  At our September meeting, let's talk about what labs and centers you would like to visit as part of the Undergraduate Research Club. Be part of the decisions!  Open to all majors in all years of college.

item.title: Undergraduate Research Club (PIZZA!! and Resumes)
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded:
Presented in ASCC (Lighty 160-180)

PUT YOUR BEST SELF FORWARD:  Come to this resume-and-career night to eat pizza (!) and learn from Career Counselor James Bledsoe about writing a meaningful resume that will open doors for you to mentored research, internships, and even jobs.  The WSU Undergraduate Research Club is open to all majors in all years of college. This is the final meeting for fall semester.

item.title: Doing Research as a Global Campus Student
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: How can Global Campus students participate in, and reap benefits from, research (which includes scholarly and creative activities)?  Get the latest information and ideas from two faculty members interested in your success:  Shelley Pressley, director of the WSU Office of Undergraduate Research, and Lee Daffin, director of the Online Psychology Degree Program who also mentors Global Campus undergraduates in research. In the recent past, Global Campus students have presented the results of their research at the annual Showcase for Undergraduate Research and Creative Activities (SURCA) in Pullman--and been eligible for awards. Information about attending this presentation will be sent to you following registration for this event online at https://connections.wsu.edu/doing-research-as-a-global-campus-student/ .

item.title: For Faculty: Incorporating Undergraduates into Your Research
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded:
Shelley Pressley, director of the WSU Office of Undergraduate Research, will share methods and best practices for incorporating undergraduates into in faculty research. Is the faculty member interested in working with undergraduates to advance research and scholarly activities? This session will cover topics related to undergraduate research including how to effectively mentor students, efficiently manage their time, and where to find support for students that are engaged in research programs. Hear about models that faculty across the campus have used to grow their research, as well as provide hands-on opportunities for students.

Part of Research Week, this presentation is hosted by the WSU Office of Research Advancement and Partnerships. The office requests faculty members wishing to attend submit an RSVP.

item.title: Award application deadline for 2019-20
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: Applications for undergraduate research awards for the 2019-20 academic year close Feb. 15, 2019. These include Auvil, Carson, and DeVlieg awards from the Office of Undergraduate Research, part of WSU Undergraduate Education.

item.title: SURCA 2019 application deadline
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: If you want to share your work at SURCA 2019 (on March 25 in the CUB M.G. Carey Senior Ballroom), you must submit your application with your abstract by Feb. 25, 2019. SURCA is the annual Showcase for Undergraduate Research and Creative Activities, and is the only WSU dissemination venue available to all student researchers from all disciplines and campuses. Prizes are awarded to top presenters in each of eight categories. Learn more at SURCA.wsu.edu.

Presented in SPARK 227

All students are welcome at the Research Extravaganza!  Learn from the Office of Undergraduate Research about opportunities for you, as a student, to get involved in hands-on mentored research, scholarship, and creative activities on campus.

item.title: Undergraduate Research Club meeting
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: How do iron fish improve the health of humans?   The Undergraduate Research Club hosts Kathy Beerman, professor and researcher in the School of Biological Sciences, for a presentation on her research and efforts in Guatemala. Beerman volunteers with Hearts in Motion on a project to prevent human anemia, and works with WSU student volunteers who spend 10 days helping measure and assess iron levels of rural inhabitants. To boost families' level of iron in their diets, an iron fish is provided to "cook" in boiling water or foods. Does it work?  Read more about her at https://sbs.wsu.edu/kathy-beerman/.

item.title: Psychology Dept.'s Undergraduate Research Symposium 2019
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded:
LOCATION: Posters in CUE Atrium; Guest speaker presentation in CUE 202

Poster presentations on student research, plus a guest speaker, highlight the Psychology Dept.'s Undergraduate Research Symposium 2019.

  • 2:30-3:00 p.m.:  Poster viewing  Posters showcasing undergraduate research projects can be viewed in the CUE Atrium.
  • 3:00-4:00 p.m.:  Guest speaker   Matthew D. Johnson will deliver a presentation in CUE 202.
  • 4:00-5:00 p.m.:  Formal poster session    Researchers will be available to discuss their projects and answer questions; reception with refreshments.

item.title: College of Education's Bruya-Wood Undergraduate Research Conference (spring 2019)
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded:
TIME AND LOCATION: To be announced; please check back soon for updated information. (Note that the time information shown in the header of this post is a placeholder; it is subject to change.)

The WSU College of Education’s semi‑annual Bruya‑Wood Undergraduate Research Conference for spring 2019 features posters by student researchers. The conference, which is hosted twice a year by the college’s kinesiology program on the Pullman campus, showcases the work of undergraduates who seized the chance to both conduct research and learn how to effectively present it, often to a lay audience. A panel of judges hears the presentations and has the opportunity to ask questions.  Read about a fall 2018 grand prize award winner, Collette Edge, at https://education.wsu.edu/2018/12/18/bruyawood2018/.

item.title: UNIV 199 (Research Prep Course) session one
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: This popular "Introduction to Directed Research" course is offered in spring 2019 on two Saturdays: Jan. 26 and Feb. 2.  It is geared toward students who are interested in participating in research, scholarship, and creative activities with a faculty mentor. Offered for 1-3 credits, the course is led by Shelley Pressley, WSU director of the Office of Undergraduate Research, and experienced peer mentors.

item.title: Summer Undergraduate Research Information Session
item.dc:creator: daniel.rieck
item.content:encoded:
Hear about summer undergraduate research opportunities both at WSU and beyond. These opportunities provide the chance to travel, gain experience, and maybe even get paid. At this session presented by Shelley Pressley, director of the WSU Office of Undergraduate Research, topics covered will include how to find a summer-research opportunity, an overview of the application process, and information about the kinds of programs available.

All undergraduates interested in learning more about these experiences are encouraged to attend this session.

item.title: Virtual STEM Recruitment Fair with 25 U.S. DOE Sponsored Programs
item.dc:creator: daniel.rieck
item.content:encoded:
The Oak Ridge Institute for Science and Education (ORISE) will be hosting a virtual recruitment fair that will showcase more than 25 programs all sponsored by the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE). The programs featured take place across the DOE complex including headquarters, laboratories, field offices, and more, and many of them involve paid STEM internships intended for undergraduate students. During the fair, you will be able to chat with recruiters and scientists, and virtually explore booths representing programs in energy-related research, policy and technology.

You can register for and attend the Virtual Recruitment Fair at the 6Connex website that will host the event. ORISE has provided an informational flyer about the virtual recruitment fair which containing more details.

item.title: URClub: CISER Information and Presentation on Research Positions
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded:
The Center for Interdisciplinary Statistical Education and Research (CISER) is a group that works with those interested in promoting quality statistical research. CISER seeks to recruit new undergraduates to participate.

CISER, for example, helps WSU colleges (and the broader community) by offering "engaged learning" hours to improve general understanding of statistical methods and techniques by working closely with a statistician on problems related to research, and to improve the quality of statistical analyses in WSU proposals, projects, and papers. CISER provides for the greater community independent and joint data analysis, algorithm development for continuous results, design of interactive visual mapping and analysis, and many more dynamic resources upon request.

Learn more from CISER experts at this Undergraduate Research Club meeting. Refreshments will be available!

item.title: URClub: Resume Workshop
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: Is there a trick to creating a great resume? Hear from students who have had success. This Undergraduate Research Club meeting will be filled with great tips and guidance for novice and experienced resume writers alike.

item.title: SURCA 2020: Undergraduate poster session with awards
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded:
The eighth annual Showcase for Undergraduate Research and Creative Activities (SURCA) is set for Monday March 30 in the CUB Senior Ballroom.  The mentored research, scholarship, and creative activity of around 200 students is presented each year at this unique event--the only one at WSU to feature the work of students from all majors, every campus, in every year of their baccalaureate education.  Expert judges evaluate each presenter, and awards are offered in eight categories.  SURCA is part of WSU Showcase Week.  Read more online at https://SURCA.wsu.edu.  Learn about open times, the awards presentation, and more.

Want to be a SURCA presenter? Abstracts must be submitted by Feb. 20! Get details on the website.

item.title: SURCA Abstract Deadline February 20
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: Abstract submissions to apply to present at SURCA 2020 on March 30 are due today!  All information and forms are online on the https://SURCA.wsu.edu website.  More than 200 students present their research, scholarship, and creative activity outcomes at this popular annual poster event.  "SURCA" is the acronym for the WSU Showcase for Undergraduate Research and Creative Activities." SURCA is part of WSU Showcase Week. Undergraduates making top presentations in eight categories receive awards. Check the schedule online to see all relevant times for that day's activities.

item.title: UGR Awards Application: Eligibility Criteria
item.dc:creator: daniel.rieck
item.content:encoded:
To indicate which award(s) you are applying for, please select one or more scholarship/fellowship from the selections below. Please check your eligibility before selecting a scholarship.

Auvil Scholars Fellowship

  • Open to all class standings
  • Open to all majors
  • Preference given to new researchers

Carson Undergradute Research Excellence Award

  • Preference given to juniors, seniors
  • Open to all majors

DeVlieg Foundation Award

  • Open to sophomores, juniors
  • Major must be in Voiland College of Engineering and Architecture
  • Must have a GPA of 3.0 or better
  • Research project must be in area of renewable energy

WSU LSAMP Research Award

  • Open to STEM majors
  • Recipients must be underrepresented minority students
  • Must have a GPA of 3.0 or better
  • Recipients must actively participate in LSAMP programs

item.title: UGR Awards Application: Mentor Notification
item.dc:creator: daniel.rieck
item.content:encoded: Dear {Full Name of Faculty Mentor (First):20.3}: This is an automated message being sent to notify you that {Student Full Name (First):4.3} {Student Full Name (Last):4.6} wishes to have you send a letter of recommendation supporting his or her application for Undergraduate Research Awards from our office. Please submit your letter of recommendation by Saturday, February 22, 2020 using our online form: https://undergraduateresearch.wsu.edu/funding/undergraduate-research-awards/letters-of-recommendation/ The student has made the following scholarship selections in their application: {:9:value}. Information about these scholarships is available on the undergraduate research website. Through the generosity of many private donations and in partnership with the NSF-funded WSU LSAMP program, the Office of Undergraduate Research at Washington State University is sponsoring independent undergraduate research, scholarship, or creative activity projects that are supervised by a WSU faculty or staff member. It was indicated in the application submitted by {Student Full Name (First):4.3} that you are his or her mentor, hence the reason for this request. In preparing your letter of recommendation for {Student Full Name (First):4.3}, please submit your letter by Saturday, February 22, 2020. Thank you for your support.
